body_html:
Hi Ouwen,

Thanks for the ping.

I can update the PR so that we add tf.float16 into the _TF_TO_IS_OK dictionary for
consistent assertion. Additionally, I will make a note that tensors with None values can have
differing behavior from NumPy in the documentation.

Both vrv and mrry suggested josh11b decide, and josh11b sent alextp. So I think the None issue is settled, and this is the right direction.

I think everyone agrees that float16 should follow the same rules as the other floats, and that the discrepancy between tf and numpy should be documented so the intent is clear (you could also note the strings with null bytes difference that alextp mentioned).

Thanks again.

consistent assertion. Additionally, I will make a note that tensors with None values can have

Both vrv and mrry suggested josh11b decide, and josh11b sent alextp. So I think the None issue is settled, and this is the right direction.
I think everyone agrees that float16 should follow the same rules as the other floats, and that the discrepancy between tf and numpy should be documented so the intent is clear (you could also note the strings with null bytes difference that alextp mentioned).
Thanks again.
body:
Hi Ouwen,

Thanks for the ping.

>  I can update the PR so that we add tf.float16 into the _TF_TO_IS_OK dictionary for 
> consistent assertion. Additionally, I will make a note that tensors with None values can have
> differing behavior from NumPy in the documentation.

Both vrv and mrry suggested josh11b decide, and josh11b sent alextp. So I think the `None` issue is settled, and this is the right direction.

I think everyone agrees that float16 should follow the same rules as the other floats, and that the discrepancy between tf and numpy should be documented so the intent is clear (you could also note the strings with null bytes difference that alextp mentioned).

Thanks again.
